etymologies: Old English antefn, antifne (denoting a composition sung antiphonally), from late Latin antiphona (see antiphon). The spelling with th, which began in the 16th century, was on the pattern of similar words such as Antony, Anthony

definitions: a rousing or uplifting song identified with a particular group, body, or cause

examples.text: the song became the anthem for hippie activists

shortDefinitions: rousing or uplifting song identified with particular group or cause

definitions: a solemn patriotic song officially adopted by a country as an expression of national identity

examples.text: the crowd stood and sang the national anthem
we decided that the match would not have the anthems of either country as a prelude

shortDefinitions: solemn patriotic song officially adopted by country as expression of national identity

definitions: a choral composition based on a biblical passage, for singing by a choir in a church service.
shortDefinitions: musical setting of religious text to be sung by choir during church service
